newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee recovers from lows on NY strength.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee recovers from lows on NY strength.

text.p: Robusta coffee futures seesawed to end tightly mixed after further advances in New York lifted prices that had been hammered by origin and fund selling.
"The market was dragged up by New York," said one trader. "It's a New York-led market at the moment and London will follow if New York displays exceptional strength."
London prices gapped marginally higher at the open but quickly moved into the minus column as origin and fund selling emerged to capitalise on Tuesday's sharp gains.
By the close, most-active January was $2 off at $1,425 a tonne after ranging from between $1,401 and $1,432.
March was also $2 lower at $1,378 while front-month November was $9 down at $1,538. The remaining months were up $2 to $8 up.
November's premium to January, an indicator of nearby supply tightness, remained at a hefty $113 at tbe close. Overall volume was 4,504 lots.
New York arabica coffee futures shot up toward midday but traders noted the market's strength centred on the spot December contract, reflecting persistent nearby supply woes.

Traders said with almost negligible U.S. certified stocks no longer seen as a major market influence, the attention is now turned to the situation in key grower Colombia as a truckers' strike entered its 10th day Wednesday.
"People are looking now at the Colombian situation and arrivals from Mexico and Costa Rica," said one.

The country's coffee chief Jorge Cardenas said on Tuesday the strike had paralysed the nation's coffee industry and forced delays in the shipment of about 250,000 60-kg bags of coffee promised for delivery in October, or a quarter of the month's total.
